summary: The Project Manager went over decisions from the previous meeting. The Industrial Designer presented the prototype and discussed its look, its internal components, and its interface. The Marketing Expert evaluated the product according to the initial product goals. The group then decided that enough of this criteria had been satisfied for the project to continue. The Project Manager presented the final cost of the device which exceeded the initial projected price point. The group decided to remove speech recognition but to propose to the management that it  remain in the design. The group then discussed their effectiveness as a team. All members felt that they interacted well and that they felt they could be creative. The Marketing Expert felt that the market-research based approach would help the project's success with consumers. The group did express, however, that the budget was overly constraining. The Project Manager instructed the group to fill out a final evaluation questionnaire.
actions: The group will suggest to the management that speech recognition remain in the product design. All members will fill out a final evaluation questionnaire.
decisions: It was decided that the speech recognition component seemed feasible, so it was added to the prototype design to provide a device locator function. It was removed when the project exceeded its initial budget, but it will be suggested to the management that the speech recognition should remain in the product design. The plastic case will be a neutral color, and the changeable rubber cases will be available in vibrant, fruit colors. The LCD screen will appear only in black and white. The company logo will appear on the inside of the device when opened. The group decided that the device fulfilled enough of the project's initial goals to continue in production.
problems: There was a lack of cost information at the beginning of the project. The group did not know how much the features made available to them actually cost until the prototype was constructed; their prototype design may have been different had this information been available at the beginning.

0: Presented by: William Cooke, Industrial Designer
1: Method

The press of the button should activate the TV
Should be able to find easily
Looked into AVAILABILITY of materials
2: Findings

Main chip used is a “TA11835”, these are standard and used in most remote controls.
Battery options: 
		Standard AA,AAA
		Dynamo charging
		Solar Charging
		Kinetic Charging
3: Findings

Most remotes use a silicon board with rubberised buttons
When the button is pressed it sends a unique code to the chip
This code is processed then output by the chip and sent via the IR LED to the TV.
4:
To conserve battery life the remote should be in a ‘standby’ mode while not being used.
Case Material? 
		Plastic, Rubber, Wood, Titanium
Interface Designs?
		Rubber buttons, LCD,  Bare??

0:
Presented by:
 William Cooke & Pawan Negi, Industrial & Interface Designer
1: Exterior

Plastic body:
		Standard colour: White? Blue?
Rubber outer casing (changeable facials)	Wide choice of colours, patterns
Clamshell design
2: Interior

Batteries: Kinetic
Voice Recognition: 
		“Where is the remote?”
						“I’m Here!!”
Standard transmission with TV, using standard chips, PCB etc.
3: Interface

Top Screen: B&W LCD Touch screen
Bottom Screen: Rubberised Standard Buttons inc. Volume, Power etc.
Also containing the new logo!

And that’s how we’ve put the fashion back into electronics!

0: Presented by: William Cooke, Industrial Designer Extraordinaire
1: Method

What are we trying to design?
-A device which sends a signal to a TV to change its state, (e.g. power button changes on/off and vice versa)
Look at what other people have designed and take inspiration
Make sure that the new design is original
2: Findings

Most remote controls use infrared to send signals to a TV.
Most are powered by some form of battery.
Small easy to carry round
3: Components

Internal:
Power Source – Batteries
Chips – To decode the input to IR Signal
Sender – IR Bulb, Wireless range up to 5m 
External: Plastic based,
UI Design
5:
Available to a wide audience, cost low.
Should be different enough to get a good consumer base.
Small, easy to lose?

0: Presented by: Pawan Negi -User Interface Designer
1: Method

Input from other departments – Marketing and Industrial Design
Competitors
GUI or Pointing device
2: Findings

To many cluttered buttons.
Repetition of certain patterns. E.g: The volume and channel  control buttons in centre
Confusing and inconsistent
Voice recognition
3: Personal Preferences

Trendy - fruit colour
Certain standard buttons
Voice recognition

0: Presented by: Pawan Negi, User Interface Designer
1: Method

Purpose of Remote Control:
To simplify the interaction with TV
Main Feature – User friendly by being easy-to-use, trendy and engineering marvel.
Concept – A Flip top model. Main function on the top and complex function inside with browsing facility. Added features such as shock proof body, trendy design.
2: Findings

Most people prefer user friendly rather than complex remote controls
Economies of scale -Due to high volume, we could produce this design at a cheaper cost.
3: Personal Preferences

Flip top design
Trendy colours
Soft exterior plastic body and soft buttons

Thanks you for your attention. 
Any comments please.

0:
Presented by: Dale Anderson
Marketing Consultant
1: Method
Collection of criteria is based on the user requirements and trends found in the marketing reports and the marketing strategy of the Real Reaction © electronics company.
2: Findings

CRITERIA
Fancy look-and-feel
Technological innovation
Easy to use
Incorporates current fashion trends
Design minimises RSI
Easy to locate
3: Evaluation

Criteria rating with seven-point scale

1 = TRUE
7 = FALSE
To be continued on whiteboard!

0:
Presented by: <Dale Anderson
Head of Marketing
1: Method

<Usability Lab
Observation of remote control use [N=100]
2: Findings

Overall, users dislike the look-and-feel of current remote controls
75% of users find most remote controls ugly
80% of users would spend more money when a remote control would look fancy 
Current remote controls do not match well the operating behavior of the user 
75% of users said they zap a lot 
50% of users say they only use 10% of the buttons
3: Personal Preferences

BIGGEST FRUSTRATIONS
Remote controls often lost in room [50%]
Takes too much time to learn to use [34%]
Bad for RSI [26%]
Vast majority of 35 and under age group want LCD display and speech recognition
Trend reverses in older age groups

1: Method

MARKET TRENDS
Market research study [N=100] on most important aspects required in a Remote Control device.

FASHION UPDATE [Personal Preferences]
Findings from fashion and design fairs in Paris and Milan.
2: Findings

MARKET TRENDS
Most Important Aspects for Remote Controls

Fancy Look-and-Feel
Technologically Innovative
Easy to Use
3: Personal Preferences

FASHION UPDATE

FRUIT & VEGETABLES will be the theme for clothes, shoes & furniture

There will be a SPONGY feel to materials

Minutes of Meeting 2:

A brief presentation by all members on their finding and suggestions

1. Industrial Designer – 

Findings - the interface between TV and remote control



2. User Interface Designer – 

Finding – People want simple and user friendly design. Not too complicated

Suggestions – A flip top design with main features on the top. A different/trendy design



3. Marketing expert –

Findings – People find the current remote controls ugly, mostly only 10% of the buttons used, misplacing the device, demand for LCD or speech recognition



Project manager coordinated to put all these ideas into a final design. The outcome:

Remote control for TV only

Incorporate the Corporate Logo

Rechargable batteries

User friendly manual

Flip top design

A different and interesting look – e,.g: a shell, conch etc

Soft buttons or touch screen

A detection device to trace it, if lost

Minutes of the meeting

Agenda: Development of new Television remote control

Participants: Project Manager, Industrial Designer, user Interface Designer and Marketing Expert

Duration: 30 minutes



The meeting started with the Project Manager defining the agenda, the concept (trendy, original and user friendly) and financial guidelines (Price Euro 20, Production cost: Euro 12.5) for the product. To break the ice, all members drew their favourite animal. The discussion started with brainstorming on the main features. Some of the suggestions were multi-utility concept (i.e. the same remote control for TV, Video and audio devices), a user friendly browsing menu (similar to the mobile phone menu) and a flip top design (to add more features and yet keep it compact). In certain ideas, such as flip-top design, concerns were expressed on the financial costs. 

Overall, the meeting was very interactive with all members expressing their opinion in a constructive and democratic way.

Minutes for meting 4					approx time 40min









The industrial designer and user interface designer began once the minutes had been reviewed; they presented their prototype design to the rest of the group and highlighted key features;

	


	There will be a central core, which is neutral – white/light blue

	The LCD screen is set in to the handset so that it closes fully

	Voice recognition should be used in order to find the remote if it lost

	It will use IR transmission and 2 separate PCB’s

	The touch screen will be black and white to save on costs

	The lower half of the design will have the very basic buttons on it; volume, power, programme etc.

	

	

	The evaluation was given by the marketing expert;

	

	We scored the highest on incorporating current fashion and ease of use.

	Our lowest was that the design minimises RSI, however we considered our attention to this area to be acceptable.

	

	We then looked at the financial feasibility of the project;

	

	We had to change the design to a flat design from double curved. We would make up for this in the shape of the foam cover.

	We also had to abandon the voice recognition software because of our budget, however we still recommend that this is pursued.

Minutes from meeting number 1:			meeting duration 25min





All of the members of the team are introduced to each other.

The main aims for the product were discussed; trendy, user friendly & original

The group then took turns at drawing their favourite animal and summarising what characteristics they associated that animal with.

The selling price and budget were discussed, highlighting that we might have dissonance between the budget and our ‘ideal’ design.

Our product will sell at 25 euros and our production is 12.50 euros.



We then discussed our first thoughts and ideas;



We decided upon a 'universal control' one handset for all your TV. and video equipment.

We decided that It is important that the product be accessible to a wide age-range of consumers.

We decided that it was important to reflect the company's image in our product, 'We put the fashion in electronics'.

Our budget will affect the specific design of the product, we want it to look trendy but not expensive to produce - silver plastic etc.

We want the control to look uncluttered and un-daunting to the consumer.

A flip open design was discussed, which would reduce the size of the control.

An electronic panel should be inside for further features such as teletext, programming and sound functions.

Minutes from meeting number 2			      approx time meeting took; 40min







Functional design meeting;



Session opened with the minutes from last meeting, then each member of the team presents their latest work.



Industry designer talked about the different options available for batteries, AA, AAA, rechargeable.

If we used rechargeable, there would be a port in which it sat overnight etc. This would also have an option on it, which can alert the consumer to the control’s whereabouts if it is lost.

It was said that in general the cost of general components should be quite low.

Our product needs to be different, as everything else in the market is much the same.

The User Interface designer talked about having soft buttons and bright colours to try and fit with what is in greatest demand.

The Marketing Expert raised a few issues; that people rarely use all of the buttons available to them anyway, so by reducing what we put on our control we are meeting the customer’s needs and reducing costs for ourselves.

Size was also mentioned, in reference to how easily lost controls are. If it is too small, it would make this problem worse.

Speech recognition software was mentioned, as more research is being carried out in this field, it is a real option for our consideration.

It was decided that there would not be the usual video programming options, instead we will use ‘video plus’, which will be an advertising point.

We have decided that our target audience is the ‘Young professional’.

	

	Our brief changed; 

	we are not to incorporate teletext into our design,

	It is not to be an all-encompassing control, just TV and video,

	Our corporate image is to be heavily incorporated into the design

Minutes of Meeting 2:

A brief presentation by all members on their finding and suggestions

1. Industrial Designer – 

Findings - the interface between TV and remote control



2. User Interface Designer – 

Finding – People want simple and user friendly design. Not too complicated

Suggestions – A flip top design with main features on the top. A different/trendy design



3. Marketing expert –

Findings – People find the current remote controls ugly, mostly only 10% of the buttons used, misplacing the device, demand for LCD or speech recognition



Project manager coordinated to put all these ideas into a final design. The outcome:

Remote control for TV only

Incorporate the Corporate Logo

Rechargable batteries

User friendly manual

Flip top design

A different and interesting look – e,.g: a shell, conch etc

Soft buttons or touch screen

A detection device to trace it, if lost

Minutes of the meeting

Agenda: Development of new Television remote control

Participants: Project Manager, Industrial Designer, user Interface Designer and Marketing Expert

Duration: 30 minutes



The meeting started with the Project Manager defining the agenda, the concept (trendy, original and user friendly) and financial guidelines (Price Euro 20, Production cost: Euro 12.5) for the product. To break the ice, all members drew their favourite animal. The discussion started with brainstorming on the main features. Some of the suggestions were multi-utility concept (i.e. the same remote control for TV, Video and audio devices), a user friendly browsing menu (similar to the mobile phone menu) and a flip top design (to add more features and yet keep it compact). In certain ideas, such as flip-top design, concerns were expressed on the financial costs. 

Overall, the meeting was very interactive with all members expressing their opinion in a constructive and democratic way.
